channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Violence Flares in West Bank and Gaza as Palestinians Desecrate a Jewish Site
item.description: An arson attack at Joseph’s Tomb punctuated another day of anti-Israeli protests by Palestinians in parts of the occupied West Bank and in Gaza. The violence left at least four dead.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Security forces examined a Palestinian man and the Israeli soldier he stabbed at a checkpoint near Hebron in the West Bank on Friday.

item.title: Iraqi Forces and Shiite Militias Retake Oil Refinery From ISIS
item.description: The defeat of Islamic State forces at the Baiji refinery is one of the first significant indications of progress against the extremist group in months.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Russia and Allies to Raise Guard at Borders With Afghanistan
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin and leaders of former Soviet states established a joint task force to counter any terrorist threats to Central Asia.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Zhang Gan on Managing the Chinese Art Market
item.description: Zhang Gan, a leader of an initiative in China to offer a master’s degree in the business of art, discussed the program and the ups and downs of China’s art market.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and MIA LI
item.media:description: Zhang Gan, vice dean of Tsinghua’s Academy of Arts and Design

item.title: Leaders of France’s Socialist Party Defy Its Orthodoxy
item.description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls and the economy minister, Emmanuel Macron, are charting a more moderate course and angering the old guard as the party struggles for direction.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France, center, with Prime Minister Manuel Valls, left, and Emmanuel Macron, the economy minister, in Paris in June. Despite the turbulence Mr. Macron and Mr. Valls have created within the Socialist Party, the president has shown no sign of reining them in.

item.title: Ethiopian Bloggers Cleared of Terrorism Charges
item.description: The case against the 10 bloggers and journalists became a rallying cry for critics of Ethiopia’s government, who accused it of stifling free speech
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Afghan Plan to Expand Militia Raises Abuse Concerns
item.description: Facing an aggressive offensive from the Taliban, the government wants to expand the Afghan Local Police, despite their troubled history.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Afghan militiamen fighting the Taliban outside Kunduz in May.

item.title: Hungary to Close Its Border With Croatia in Migrant Crackdown
item.description: The Hungarian foreign minister said the country was taking action because the European Union had yet to come up with a comprehensive plan to deal with the flow of people.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Migrants who had arrived by train in Botovo, Croatia, walked toward the border with Hungary on Friday.

item.title: Indian Supreme Court Rules Against Modi’s Judge Selection Law
item.description: In a decision hailed as a landmark, the law, which sought to increase executive branch’s power over the decisions, was deemed unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: South Korean Leader Meeting With Obama
item.description: President Park Geun-hye and Mr. Obama were expected to discuss ways to present a united front against North Korean.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea at the Pentagon on Thursday. She was scheduled to meet President Obama on Friday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: British Museum’s Director Follows a Fascination to Germany
item.description: Neil MacGregor will leave his post in Britain to help shape one of Germany’s most audacious cultural projects, the Humboldt Forum.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neil MacGregor, who is leaving his post as director of the British Museum, will help to shape the Humboldt Forum, intended to frame Germany’s historical and artistic relationship with the world.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: On the Afghanistan Troop Reversal
item.description: President Obama halted the withdrawal of American military forces from Afghanistan this week.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Turkish Jets Shoot Down Drone Near Syria
item.description: “Our aircraft on patrol mission on the border fired and shot down the vehicle within the rules of engagement,” Turkey’s military said.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Our Vanishing Flowers
item.description: In a staggering loss of diversity, 68 percent of the world's flowering plants are threatened or endangered.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN L. BUCHMANN
item.media:description: Pediocactus despainii, a highly endangered cactus limited to a small strip overlooking Utah's San Rafael Swell, spends most of its life underground, emerging for only a few days to flower before retracting into the desert sand.

item.title: Nigeria President Escalates Campaign to Stem Corruption
item.description: Since assuming power in May, President Muhammadu Buhari has squeezed the flow of public funds in an effort to clean up Africa’s biggest economy.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Glenna Gordon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Legislators from southeast Nigeria attended an anticorruption training session on Wednesday in Abuja, the capital.

item.title: South Korean President Says She’s Open to Talks With Japanese Leader
item.description: A summit of Park Geun-hye and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan would be welcomed by Washington, which wants its main East Asian allies to mend ties.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: 공연리뷰: 빅뱅, 케이팝의 각본을 화려하게 빛내다
item.description: 데뷔 10년, 재능있는 이들로 넘쳐날 뿐 아니라 새로운 피가 끊임없이 수혈되는 케이팝의 세계에서 빅뱅은 가장 혁신적이고 인기 있는 그룹의 자리를 지켜왔다.
item.dc:creator: JON CARAMANICA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: With Anti-Muslim Campaign, Canada Has Its Trump Moment
item.description: Used to the moral high ground, Canadians are watching their own politics getting dragged into divisive immigrant-bashing.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN PATRIQUIN
item.media:credit: Jonathan Hayward/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press

item.title: Migrant Crisis Leads to Calls for Tighter Borders in Europe
item.description: Gathering in Brussels, European leaders also endorsed a push to get Turkey to control the flow of Syrians and others before they can reach Europe.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: A group of migrants making their way over a meadow after crossing the border between Austria and Germany in Wegscheid near Passau, Germany, on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: American Publishers Take a Stand Against Censorship in China
item.description: Their pledge is a response to a report released in May by the PEN American Center that showed how the translated works of foreign authors are sometimes published with unauthorized excisions.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters at a rally against Chinese censorship in front of the New York Public Library ahead of a BookExpo America event in May. A large delegation of publishers from China attended the trade gathering as guests of honor.
